subject: Communication
title: Emotional Triggers: When Feelings Block Hearing
description: A micro-lesson that makes Emotional Triggers: When Feelings Block Hearing usable.

hook.text: Someone says one word â€” maybe 'privilege' or 'socialism' â€” and suddenly you can't hear anything else.

buildup.text: Emotional triggers activate the amygdala, flooding the brain with cortisol and adrenaline â€” hijacking the thinking mind.

discovery.text: Once triggered, we stop listening to understand and start listening to defend.

twist.text: Triggers are personal. What shuts down one person's listening is neutral to another.

climax.text: The technique: name the emotion ('I'm feeling defensive'). Naming activates the prefrontal cortex and calms the amygdala.

punchline.text: You can't listen when your brain is in fight mode. Name the trigger.

quiz.question: What brain structure hijacks listening when we're emotionally triggered?
